bestBHT.bht: In his impassioned discourse, the apostle Paul vividly recounts how he transitioned from being a relentless enemy of Jesus to an obedient messenger of His gospel. Paul's unwavering commitment to spreading the message of the crucified Christ is evident as he fearlessly delivered it to both Jews and Gentiles, demonstrating that there is no distinction in the Messiah's kingdom. Despite facing persecution and attempts on his life, Paul persisted in fulfilling his divine calling, relying on God's help and guidance every step of the way.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: This musical and elevated strain, which carries the reader along with it, and doubtless did the hearers, bespeaks the lofty region of thought and feeling to which the apostle had risen while rehearsing his Master's communications to him from heaven.
Albert Barnes: Caught me in the temple - Acts 21:30.
And went about ... - Endeavored to put me to death.
John Calvin: For it had been a point of an unthankful man to withdraw himself from him which had holpen him.

By this let us learn that it is not in the teacher’s will to make choice of his hearers, and that they do no less injury to God than defraud men of their right, whosoever they be which restrain their labor unto great men, whom God doth join with those which are small.

Secondly, this is worth the noting, that these were the principal points of the disputation which Luke doth now touch; that this was the proper office of Christ, by his death to make satisfaction for the sins of the world, by his resurrection to purchase righteousness and life for men; and that the fruit of his death and resurrection is common both to Jews and Gentiles.
Philip Schaff: He, Saul, once the determined relentless enemy of the ‘crucified Nazarene,’ now obeyed His voice, and went about everywhere delivering the message of the ‘Crucified’ with power.

He delivered the message indifferently to the hated Gentiles as to the favoured Jews, thereby proclaiming that in Messiah’s kingdom there would be no difference between the children of Israel and the children born in the darkness of the isles of the Gentiles.
...thereby proclaiming that in Messiah’s kingdom there would be no difference between the children of Israel and the children born in the darkness of the isles of the Gentiles.
Archibald T. Robertson: Assayed to kill me (επειρωντο διαχειρισασθα). Conative imperfect middle of πειραω, the old form of the later Koine πειραζω so common in the Koine."
The old verb διαχειριζω, to take in hand, middle to lay hands on, to slay, occurs in N.T. only here and Acts 5:30 which see.
John Gill: For these causes the Jews caught me in the temple
...for preaching the above doctrines to them
John Wesley: For these things — The apostle now applies all that he had said.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Acts 26:21, the apostle Paul passionately recounts his encounters with Jesus and the calling he received from Him. He describes how he went from being a persecutor of Christians to a faithful messenger of the crucified Christ, fervently delivering His message to both Jews and Gentiles. The gravity of Paul's testimony is reflected in his choice of words, particularly when he mentions how the Jews caught him in the temple and tried to kill him. This intense opposition underscores the importance of the message Paul was proclaiming, as it revealed that in the kingdom of Christ, there would be no distinction between Jews and Gentiles. The profound significance of Jesus' death and resurrection, which brings righteousness and life to all, is a central theme in Paul's discourse. Despite the dangers and hardships he faced, Paul remained steadfast in his mission, knowing that it was God who had helped him and guided him on this transformative journey.

In his passionate testimony, the apostle Paul eloquently shares how he went from being a persecutor of Christians to a dedicated messenger of Jesus. He boldly proclaimed the message of the crucified Christ, bringing hope and salvation to both Jews and Gentiles alike. Despite facing intense opposition from the Jews who sought to kill him, Paul remained resolute in his mission, knowing that it was God who had aided him. His experiences highlight the profound significance of Jesus' death and resurrection, which extended to all, regardless of their backgrounds.

In Acts 26:21, the apostle Paul passionately recounts his transformation from a persecutor to a messenger of Jesus. He fearlessly delivered the message of the crucified Christ, embracing both Jews and Gentiles, proclaiming the equality found in the kingdom of Christ. Despite facing opposition and threats to his life, Paul remained steadfast in fulfilling his calling, knowing that it was God who had supported him. His testimony highlights the profound impact of Jesus' death and resurrection, extending redemption and life to all.

In his impassioned discourse, the apostle Paul vividly recounts how he transitioned from being a relentless enemy of Jesus to an obedient messenger of His gospel. Paul's unwavering commitment to spreading the message of the crucified Christ is evident as he fearlessly delivered it to both Jews and Gentiles, demonstrating that there is no distinction in the Messiah's kingdom. Despite facing persecution and attempts on his life, Paul persisted in fulfilling his divine calling, relying on God's help and guidance every step of the way.

In Acts 26:21, the apostle Paul passionately shares his transformation from being a persecutor to a messenger of Jesus. He fearlessly proclaimed the message of the crucified Christ, delivering it to all, irrespective of their background. Despite encountering opposition, Paul remained steadfast, knowing that it was God who had helped him on this journey. This testimony emphasizes the profound significance of Jesus' death and resurrection, extending righteousness and life to both Jews and Gentiles in the kingdom of Christ.
